description:
Amycolatopsis speibonae is a species of actinobacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Germany. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. The cells of A. speibonae are typically rod-shaped and can form hypha-like structures.

Phylogenetically, A. speibonae belongs to the genus Amycolatopsis, which is part of the family Pseudonocardiaceae within the order Actinomycetales. The genus Amycolatopsis includes several species known for their ability to produce various secondary metabolites, including antibiotics and enzymes.

Biochemically, A. speibonae is characterized by its ability to utilize a range of carbon sources for growth, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose. It is also known to have the capacity to degrade complex biopolymers, such as cellulose and xylan, which can be of potential interest in industrial applications.

The genome of A. speibonae has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential for biotechnological applications. Further research on this species may uncover its ecological roles and potential for producing novel bioactive compounds.
